input:
CONVERSATION HISTORY:
[
  "DOCTOR: What brings you in today?",
  "PATIENT: Well, I\u2019ve been feeling dizzy sometimes when I turn my head or lie down, and it only lasts a little while, but it worries me about falling or getting hurt.",
  "DOCTOR: When did you first notice these dizziness episodes, and how have they changed over time?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, I first noticed it maybe two weeks ago, I guess. It kind of comes on suddenly and then goes away pretty fast, like in less than a minute. It mostly happens when I turn my head quickly or when I lie down or roll over in bed. Sometimes I feel kind of nauseous during those spells, but I don't hear anything strange or feel hearing loss. It\u2019s been happening more frequently lately, I think. I don\u2019t really know if it\u2019s gotten worse or better, but it\u2019s definitely bothering me. I'm worried because I don't know what\u2019s causing it or if I should be more concerned."
]

The patient's age and gender are not explicitly stated in this conversation but are assumed to be unknown. Missing information includes the exact onset timing, frequency, severity, associated symptoms, medical history, and any recent activities related to the dizziness.

input:
CONVERSATION HISTORY:
[
  "DOCTOR: What brings you in today?",
  "PATIENT: Well, I\u2019ve been feeling dizzy sometimes when I turn my head or lie down, and it only lasts a little while, but it worries me about falling or getting hurt.",
  "DOCTOR: When did you first notice these dizziness episodes, and how have they changed over time?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, I first noticed it maybe two weeks ago, I guess. It kind of comes on suddenly and then goes away pretty fast, like in less than a minute. It mostly happens when I turn my head quickly or when I lie down or roll over in bed. Sometimes I feel kind of nauseous during those spells, but I don't hear anything strange or feel hearing loss. [
  "DOCTOR: What brings you in today?",
  "PATIENT: Well, I\u2019ve been feeling dizzy sometimes when I turn my head or lie down, and it only lasts a little while, but it worries me about falling or getting hurt.",
  "DOCTOR: When did you first notice these dizziness episodes, and how have they changed over time?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, I first noticed it maybe two weeks ago, I guess. It kind of comes on suddenly and then goes away pretty fast, like in less than a minute. It mostly happens when I turn my head quickly or when I lie down or roll over in bed. Sometimes I feel kind of nauseous during those spells, but I don't hear anything strange or feel hearing loss. It\u2019s been happening more frequently lately, I think. I don\u2019t really know if it\u2019s gotten worse or better, but it\u2019s definitely bothering me.   "DOCTOR: Can you tell me how often these dizziness episodes are happening now and whether they have become more or less frequent recently?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, I think they happen a little more often now. At first, it was just kind of when I turned my head quickly, but lately, it feels like it's happening a bit more, and sometimes I get dizzy even just lying down or rolling over in bed. But I'm not sure if that's a big difference or not.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you describe how many times you experience these dizziness episodes each day or week, and how they affect your activities?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, I think I sometimes get dizzy... maybe like a few times a day? It\u2019s kind of hard to say exactly, but definitely when I turn my head or get into bed. I haven\u2019t counted how many times exactly, but it\u2019s been happening more often over the last couple of weeks."
]

input:
CONVERSATION HISTORY:
[
  "DOCTOR: What brings you in today?",
  "PATIENT: Well, I\u2019ve been feeling dizzy sometimes when I turn my head or lie down, and it only lasts a little while, but it worries me about falling or getting hurt.",
  "DOCTOR: When did you first notice these dizziness episodes, and how have they changed over time?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, I first noticed it maybe two weeks ago, I guess. It kind of comes on suddenly and then goes away pretty fast, like in less than a minute. It mostly happens when I turn my head quickly or when I lie down or roll over in bed. Sometimes I feel kind of nauseous during those spells, but I don't hear anything strange or feel hearing loss. It\u2019s been happening more frequently lately, I think. I don\u2019t really know if it\u2019s gotten worse or better, but it\u2019s definitely bothering me. I'm worried because I don't know what\u2019s causing it or if I should be more concerned.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you tell me how often these dizziness episodes are happening now and whether they have become more or less frequent recently?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, I think they happen a little more often now. At first, it was just kind of when I turned my head quickly, but lately, it feels like it's happening a bit more, and sometimes I get dizzy even just lying down or rolling over in bed. But I'm not sure if that's a big difference or not.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you describe how many times you experience these dizziness episodes each day or week, and how they affect your activities?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, I think I sometimes get dizzy... maybe like a few times a day? It\u2019s kind of hard to say exactly, but definitely when I turn my head or get into bed. It\u2019s pretty quick, just a moment, but I feel like the room\u2019s spinning a little. Sometimes I feel a bit nauseous too during these spells, but it doesn\u2019t last long. I haven\u2019t counted how many times exactly, but it\u2019s been happening more often over the last couple of weeks.",
  "DOCTOR: Have you noticed if your dizziness improves or worsens when you sit or lie down and if your blood pressure readings are different at those times?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, yes, I do notice that when I turn my head or lie down, I feel that spinning sensation and sometimes I feel a little sick. I haven't really checked if my blood pressure changes, but I guess it might be different sometimes when I\u2019m lying down or sitting. I haven\u2019t measured it myself, though.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you describe how these dizziness episodes affect your daily activities\u2014do they cause you to lose balance, fall, or feel unsteady even after the episode ends?",
  "PATIENT: Well, um, I guess it sort of makes me feel unsteady sometimes, especially when I turn my head quickly or lie down. I haven't actually fallen or anything, but I do worry I might. It\u2019s like, I feel off balance for a little while after, but it doesn't last long. I haven't fallen, no, but I do feel pretty scared sometimes when it happens."
]
